item.title: ಕಪ್ಪೆ ಚಿಪ್ಪು, ಹಕ್ಕಿ ಪುಕ್ಕ
item.description:
ಕಪ್ಪೆ ಚಿಪ್ಪು, ಹಕ್ಕಿ ಪುಕ್ಕ

ಮನೆ ಬಾಗಿಲಿನಿಂದ ಸ್ಪೂರ್ತಿ ಕಾನ್ವೆಂಟ್ ದೂರವೇನಲ್ಲ. ಅಪ್ಪನಿಗೆ ೨೦ ಹೆಜ್ಜೆಯಾದರೆ, ಅಪ್ಪನ ಕಿರುಬೆರಳು ಹಿಡಿದ ನನಗೆ ೪೦-೫೦ ಹೆಜ್ಜೆ. ನನ್ನ ಮೊದಲ ಶಾಲೆ. ಅಲ್ಲೇ ಮುಂದಿನ ೩ ವರ್ಷ ಕಳೆದೆ. ಒಂದನೇ ತರಗತಿಗೆ ಪಕ್ಕದ ಮನೆಯ ಪುಪ್ಪಿ* ಹೋಗುತ್ತಿದ್ದ ಶಾಲೆ ಸೇರಿದ್ದಾಯಿತು. ಹೊಸ ಶಾಲೆ ಮನೆಯಿಂದ ನಡೆದು ಹೋಗುವಷ್ಟು ಹತ್ತಿರವಿರಲಿಲ್ಲ. ಬರೋಬ್ಬರಿ ೨ಕಿಮೀ ದೂರ.

ಮನೆ ವಿಳಾಸ ಬದಲಾಯಿತು, ಅದರೊಂದಿಗೆ ಶಾಲೆಯೂ. ೧೦ ವರ್ಷದ ನನಗೆ ಪೆನ್ ಉಪಯೋಗಿಸುವ ಹೊಸ ಜವಾಬ್ದಾರಿಯ ಸಂಭ್ರಮ. ಇಷ್ಟರಲ್ಲಿ ಹೋದಲ್ಲೆಲ್ಲಾ ಹೊಸಬರೊಂದಿಗೆ ಮಾತಾಡುವ ಕಲೆ ಕರಗತವಾಗಿತ್ತು. ದಿನಂಪ್ರತಿ ೪ಕಿಮೀ ಹೋಗಿ ಬರುವುದು ಅಭ್ಯಾಸವಾಗಿತ್ತು.

೭ನೇ ಕ್ಲಾಸು ದಾಟಿ ಹೈಸ್ಕೂಲ್ ಮೆಟ್ಟಿಲು ಹತ್ತಿದಾಗ ಮತ್ತೊಂದು ಶಾಲೆ. ಈ ಬಾರಿ ತಮ್ಮನೂ ನನ್ನದೇ ಶಾಲೆ. ಬಸ್ಸಿನಲ್ಲಿ ೬ಕಿಮೀ ಹೋಗಿ ಬರುತ್ತಿದ್ದೆವು. ಶಾಲೆಯ ಮೊದಲ ಬ್ಯಾಚಿನಿಂದ ಉತ್ತೀರ್ಣಳಾದೆ. ಇದು ೧೦ ವರ್ಷ ಹಿಂದಿನ ಕತೆ.

item.title: What I learnt from One Month of Crocheting
item.description:
• Making functional things takes patience, time and effort.

  • I often lack patience and time.

  • Crocheting is great for mental health - it’s meditative really. But I spend hours with terrible posture. Most times when I’ve successfully transformed a ball of yarn into something nice, I have a back ache, my legs have ants (that’s how we say ‘gone numb’ in Kannada) and my fingers are throbbing.

  • There is so much content out there that’s easily accessible. Truly grateful for the times we live in.

item.title: Some Yarn, a Bottle of Milk and the Crushing Weight of the Universe
item.description:
Home is a lot of things - the cozy corner you sip your tea in, the people you spend your weekends with, the sunlight through your window lighting up the pictures on your wall, the self-cooked slightly-burnt comfort meal, the cat who swears to get you the next time around.

It’s familiarity.

Over the last 2 weeks, I have been crocheting. Obsessively. Like there is a limited supply of yarn and I will run out of clothes if I don’t make some, like the three sisters of fate spin thread just for me. In short, I have been crocheting a lot.

item.title: Going Down a Mountain (really fast)
item.description:
“From there, it was all downhill.”

In a very very positive context. Going downhill on one of the mountains (there are at least 74. give or take 60. maybe 10. you get the point.) around Oeschinensee is one of the most exhilarating experiences ever. For multiple reasons:

  1. The blue blue waters of Oeschinensee
  2. The magnificent view of the Alps all around
  3. The green grass with white and yellow flowers
  4. The combination of all of the above at the same place
  5. The feeling of accomplishment after going uphill

Oeschinensee is one of the bluest lakes you’ll ever see. To say that the hiking paths along the lake are scenic is an understatement. For us who live in the middle of nowhere, getting there was time consuming but fairly simple: Board a train in Geneva, get off at Kandersteg. Walk from the Kandersteg railway station to Kandersteg cable car station - this should take about 15 minutes (or 45 if you stop for pictures now and then). Take the cable car up the mountain, and the hike officially starts here. Snowcapped peaks all around, grass on the hills in front of you, the pretty town of Kandersteg far far below. Oeschinensee is not in sight yet, but as you walk along, you see hidden bits of blue from in between the tree branches.

item.title: How to find warmth in sub-zero temperatures
item.description: No, Saint-Genis-Pouilly is not THAT cold. It gets cold, but it’s not to an extent where you’d lose your toes to frostbite. At most, your voice trembles and your teeth chatter and your fingers freeze over every time you need to text someone. 6°C in December is not bad. However, add to it other factors like being away from home for the first time, and it gets slightly colder. The pressure of having to do things because you’re in your early 20s and you have to enjoy life. It goes from 6°C to -10°C. The perils of starting a new life in a whole new city, country and continent whose languages and ways you don’t quite understand yet. It goes to “feels like -50°C. And you’re left looking for warmth. Because that’s what you’re used to. Warmth. 35°C. Coming home to people you love. Hanging out with friends you’ve known for years. Being fed and taken care of without a worry in the world.

item.title: Beyond
item.description:
Outside of my job, this is what I do:

Read and review books

The Humans
Flowers for Algernon
The Extraordinary Journey of the Fakir who got trapped in the IKEA Wardrobe (The author commented!)
Eleanor Oliphant is Completely Fine
The Namesake

Travel

I like to plan trips as much I like going on the trips. You can see a chronicle of my trips on my friend’s YouTube channel.

Crochet

At some point Switzerland deemed me too old for cheaper train tickets. So I picked up a crochet hook and some yarn. I’ve made coasters and handbags and crop tops and headbands and lip balm pouches and plants and-

Five to Six Lake Hike

With a magnificent view of Dents du midi

Le Reculet

Can it get more French?

Introducing everyone’s favorite cat to my mom

Luna is very non chalant. Very elegant. Very cat. She ignores you when you give her attention and then comes running behind you like she was planning to go that way anyway. She has a certain air of authority to her, like she is the one making the rules. She pretends like you’re the least important thing to her and she could not care less about you. But when you walk away she’ll run behind you nonetheless.

Running into long lost childhood friend - this time in the middle of the Italian Alps

If you’ve read this you probably think I’m a big fat liar. And you’re not entirely wrong, because this post too is about Chaithra, my school friend that I talk to everyday, who actively mindfully planned to visit and stay with me, not in the middle of Italian Alps but near the French Juras. She was slightly offended that I never told her that the word Jurassic comes from the Juras where dinosaur fossils were first found.
Trying to buy sunscreen in the middle of spring

A whole lot of nothing and a little bit of everything

There’s snow as far as eyes can see, and little else. If you squint hard enough you can probably spot a hiker or two in the distance. If you’re here and at a risk of hypothermia, you can be fairly certain that you are in Jungfraujoch, the highest railway station in Europe.

How long does a postcard take to reach home?

Approximately 3 weeks, it turns out.

How a 5-minute Helicopter Ride changed my Perception of the Universe

It didn’t. It was mad fun though.

Chateau d’oex hosts the annual hot air balloon festival every January. But only noobs go on hot air balloon rides at a hot air balloon festival. Cool People™️ go on helicopter rides. The fact that helicopter rides are way more affordable than hot air balloon rides is irrelevant.

After a year in strange land, I go home

The last two hours in the flight seem unbearable. I’ve spent a year away from home, and I feel the most homesick when I’m so close?
Biking through the Black Forest with my Mortal Enemy

Spending a night in prison without committing a crime

Lucerne is beautiful for a bunch of different reasons. For me, the reason is as plain as I went here and had a great time.

A Wedding, a Soviet Train and a Hundred Thousand Umbrellas

Diana and Alex got married. That’s where the “wedding” part of the title comes from.

They got married in their hometown in Moldova. That’s where the Soviet Train comes from.

I am a big fat liar. That’s where the hundred thousand umbrellas come from.

That is not to say there were no umbrellas at all. They were definitely there. About a hundred, maybe a hundred and fifty, not more. They adorn a pedestrian street in a canopy. Colorful in a soothing way, not in a hurts-your-eyes way.
Watching my Pistacchio ice cream fall to the streets of Morcote
Packing my life in two suitcases and a backpack

Reaching the western most point in Europe - and how we got there

Planning ahead and carefully organizing the details are important for any trip.

Except this one we just went on.

We winged every aspect of the trip that could possibly be winged, and it was insane.

Being from Mangalore, I was facing a severe lack of beaches in a land-locked Switzerland. Waving to the ocean moved me in ways I cannot describe. They moved me even as my feet were lodged in the sand. They moved my hair in ways that covered my face.

Random girl from Egypt does my eyeliner in Rome

I’ve always wanted to go on a solo trip.

Running into long lost childhood friend in the middle of the North Sea

I’ll come clean right away. Let’s break down the truth in the title:

  1. “Running into” - we actively planned for months to meet up, we did not just run into each other. I planned this trip specifically to visit and stay with said friend. This was not a coincidence.
  2. “long lost” - we talk, share memes and photos every single day.
  3. “childhood” - this is true, i met said friend at 13, that is childhood. some may argue that 13 is teenage and not childhood, but at my age 13 is definitely childhood.
  4. “friend” - said friend is way past the “friend” tier. said friend has a say in my decisions. mom loves said friend.
  5. “in the middle of the North Sea” - we met on land. we were not feeling adventurous enough to swim to the middle of the North Sea to meet each other at the time of this trip. some day we will, i think.

Now that we’ve cleared that up, we can discuss the details.

Realizing the meaning of life in a pizzeria in Turin

I did not realize the meaning of life in a pizzeria in Turin. I did however realize that Turin does have some of the most amazing pizzas. Turin also has a lot of pizzazz.

When an unexpected hiking path appears, you hike

If you’re a James Bond fan, you would love this place. Probably. I have no idea. I loved Valle Verzasca for how peaceful it is.
Going on a solo trip together

item.title: Work
item.description:
Work

I’m a Cloud Engineer at CERN. I work on OpenStack, and my day involves working on business continuity and disaster recovery, storage services of Openstack, and monitoring and observability.

My last job was at Citrix (now Cloud Software Group), where I started my career as an intern for 6 months, and then worked as a DevOps Engineer for another year and a half. I worked on Monitoring, Automation and Observability as Code. Additionally, I shadowed the activities of the security team.
